Title.evidence: Title: Randomised Controlled Trial on Complement System Modulation in Lung Transplantation

Participants.evidence: Participants were adults eligible for lung transplantation. This randomised controlled trial was conducted at a tertiary care center.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received a complement inhibitor, while the control group received standard care.

Objective.evidence: Objective: To evaluate the impact of complement inhibition on lung transplant outcomes.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of primary graft dysfunction (PGD) within 72 hours post-transplant.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised, 100 to the intervention and 100 to the control group, between January 2020 and June 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis included 98 in the intervention group and 97 in the control group, using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group showed a significant reduction in PGD incidence (mean difference = 15%, 95% CI 5% to 25%; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were mild, with 3% in the intervention group and 1% in the control group experiencing gastrointestinal side-effects.

Funding.evidence: Funding: This trial was funded by the National Institutes of Health.
